newsitem.title: CHINA: Ford says China venture will continue.
newsitem.headline: Ford says China venture will continue.

text.p: Ford Motor Co. said Friday that a steep fall in profits by its Chinese partner, Jiangling Motors Corp. Ltd., would not affect its plans to introduce light commercial vehicles late next year.
"The drop in profits will not delay the project," said Vaughn Koshkarian, president of Ford Motor (China) Ltd.
Ford's project with Jiangling, based in Nanchang in the eastern province of Jiangxi, eventually hopes to produce 60,000 light commercial vehicles a year.
The auto maker has a 20 percent stake in the venture with Jiangling, and is one of five joint venture companies producing auto parts in China.
It has invested a combined $250 million in the China market, Koshkarian said.
Earlier this month, Jiangling Motors said its net profits for the first half of 1996 had tumbled 77 percent due to a sluggish market for motor vehicles.
Car and truck makers in China have been hurt by a prolonged austerity programme by the Chinese government to keep once-surging inflation under control.
But inflation has been well within target this year and the central bank has been able to ease its tight money policies, cutting interest rates twice in less than four months.
Koshkarian said the overall market for cars and trucks this year would be 1.5 million cars, about the same as in 1995, despite a slight upturn in the second half.
"There should be some easing of the situation in the second half" because of slightly easier credit, he said.
